about patterns you can you can use to make it easy to communicate some of these changes that happen in your world to other teams that might be interested
and I think that's where kind of taking some of these domain driven Design Concepts and applying them to distributed system thinking can be
really really valuable so you know one one tradeoff you have to make pretty early if you want to adopt some
distributed systems paradigms is like the concept of eventual consistency which is something demain driven design
truthfully tries to avoid like if you follow domain driven designs from a p spec standpoint it tries to get you to
group things that are related into things we called Aggregates and those Aggregates are intended to um maintain
some sort of transactional guarantee so an example again might be something like an order if I make an order and I need
to take a payment for that order to be successful and then I also need to dispatch like a physical item right
those three things are all connected so maybe I'll wrap them in Aggregate and I'll treat them as a single thing for the purpose of of my code however the
problem is when you move to distributed systems you may have an ordering team you may have a transactions team for
example um you might have a fulfillment Team all these people need to hear about your order they may need to have a view
on it and you've got to kind of start making decisions about when is it okay for uh a transaction so almost be
eventual like when can we have eventual ual consistency within the system and when can we not and so thinking about
when that's acceptable and when it isn't is a really great conversation to have up front and if if you started to model your world in terms of Aggregates you
